subject: Home & DIY
title: Low-Flow Fixtures Save Thousands of Gallons
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Low-Flow Fixtures Save Thousands of Gallons.

hook.text: Switching to a low-flow showerhead saves a family of four over 8,000 gallons per year. You won't notice the difference.

buildup.text: Standard showerheads flow at 2.5 gallons per minute. Low-flow models use 1.5-2.0 GPM while maintaining water pressure.

discovery.text: Aerators mix air into the water stream, creating the feel of high flow with less water. The trick is air, not volume.

twist.text: Faucet aerators cost under $5 and cut sink flow 30%. They're the cheapest water-saving deviceâ€”installed in a minute.

climax.text: Low-flow fixtures also cut hot-water energy use. Less water heated means lower gas or electric bills on top of savings.

punchline.text: Air pretending to be water saves both.

quiz.question: How do low-flow showerheads maintain pressure with less water?
options: They mix air into the stream to simulate higher flow
They increase water velocity through a narrower nozzle
They pulse the water on and off very rapidly
